_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention And Emergency Response Policies

Country Fresh, LLC continues to monitor and improve its commitment to maintain and improve the facility chemical safety program. These improvements have included more awareness of chemical hazards through in-depth training during new employee orientation and annual refresher training of the Chemical Response Team. System upgrades have been incorporated in 2007-08 and constant review and maintenance of the RMP and Process Management programs is part of the overall operation. 

Facility And Regulated Substance Handling 

Country Fresh, LLC is a producer of dairy products which includes the processing, packaging and delivery of milk, cottage cheese, bottled water, and various types of dips.  The facility also has a very large freezer and several coolers used as central storage and distribution point for ice cream and yogurt.  The entire facility is located within a seventeen acre site which is comprised of manufacturing, Distribution, Garage, and offices. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program And Chemical Specific Prevention

Country Fresh, LLC complies with State of Michigan MIOSHA regulations which include Process Safety Management (PSM).  Additionally the facility complies with federal EPA requirements and State of Michigan Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) standards.

Our program of chemical safety includes:

- Technological improvements upgrading of the ammonia system,
- Management systems which results in improved maintenance using
  Preventative Maintenance, and
- Upgrading of procedures and training programs.

Five Year Accident History 

In the last five years, Country Fresh, LLC has had no accidental releases meeting the reporting criteria.  

Emergency Response Program 

Our emergency response program includes coordination of efforts through the Kent County LEPC and Wyoming Fire Department.  Additionally, specified individuals within the plant have completed emergency response training

so they may act as "specialists" in the event of ammonia releases.  These individuals receive annual refresher training.  The facility also works closely with the local fire department regarding proper chemical release notifications and coordination between all parties.  In the event of an emergency, public notification would be through the local fire department.

Changes For Improved Safety

Our programs are monitored looking for methods of continued improvement.  Second party auditors review both RMP and PSM at least every four years. Internal staffing annually reviews all health, safety, and environmental programs to insure compliance with state and/or federal regulations, corporate mandates, and internal operational performance requirements.
